subject: History
title: Medieval Surgery: Barbers and Blades
description: Learn Medieval Surgery: Barbers and Blades in one minute.

hook.text: In medieval Europe, your barber didn't just cut hair. He pulled teeth, amputated limbs, and drained blood.

buildup.text: The Church banned monks from spilling blood in 1163. Surgery fell to barbersâ€”the tradesmen with the sharpest tools.

discovery.text: Barber-surgeons could remove bladder stones, set fractures, and perform amputationsâ€”all without anesthesia.

twist.text: The red-and-white barber pole symbolizes blood and bandagesâ€”a medieval surgical advertisement still seen on streets.

climax.text: Surgery remained a low-status trade until the 1700s, when trained surgeons finally separated from barbers.

punchline.text: Your barber's pole is a medieval surgery sign.

quiz.question: Why did barbers become surgeons in medieval Europe?
options: They were the most educated tradesmen
The Church banned monks from spilling blood, so barbers took over
They invented new surgical tools for the battlefield
